masterFinding.verificationInstructions:
Instructions


Review SSL certificates deployed to web servers in scope to identify potentially subdomains or internal system names.
Note: This maybe done by Amass or API services. Still need confirm.
Below are a few options for scraping SSL

Variation: tlsx


Install tlsx:
go install github.com/projectdiscovery/tlsx/cmd/tlsx@latest

Scan (sub)domains for CN and SAN values:
cat domains.txt | tlsx -silent -cn -san -ro | sort -u

Variation: SSLScrape


Subnet scraping for 443:
git clone https://github.com/cheetz/sslScrape.git
pip install ndg-httpsclient
pip install python-masscan
sslScrape.py 10.100.100.0/24

Variation: Get-RemoteCertInfo.ps1


Scraping from list of IP:PORT
https://github.com/NetSPI/OSINT/blob/master/subdomains/Get-SSLCertInfo-Scan.psm1

open powershell or powershell_ise
set-executionatpolicy bypass -scope process
Import-module Get-SSLCertInfo-Scan.psm1
Get-SSLCertInfo-Scan -Verbose -InputFile C:\temp\list.txt
Get-SSLCertInfo-Scan -Verbose -InputFile C:\temp\list.txt -OnlyDomainList

Variation: Nessus Plugin - "SSL - Certificate Information"


Manuall review data in Nessus finding "SSL - Certificate Information".
masterFinding.remediationInstructions: Ensure that all internet facing SSL certificates are signed by a trusted certificate authority and do not contain internal asset information. Corrective actions may not be required, but it is important to be aware that data from SSL certificates can be viewed and leveraged by attackers.
masterFinding.name: General Information - Domains - SSL Certificate Scanning
masterFinding.businessImpact: Information identified could be used in future attacks.
